text:
Is this expected `hash`ing behaviour?
```julia> a = [rand(0:1, 200) for i in 1:10000]
julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
true```
It seems to be different with smaller vectors:
```julia> a = [rand(0:1, 200) for i in 1:10]
julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
false```

elements.text:

julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
true
It seems to be different with smaller vectors:

julia> a = [rand(0:1, 200) for i in 1:10]
julia> b = deepcopy(a)
julia> a[1][1] = 2
julia> hash(a) == hash(b)
false

text:
```2396  # Goal: Hash approximately log(N) entries with a higher density of hashed elements
 2397  # weighted towards the end and special consideration for repeated values. Colliding
 2398  # hashes will often subsequently be compared by equality -- and equality between arrays```

 2397  # weighted towards the end and special consideration for repeated values. Colliding
 2398  # hashes will often subsequently be compared by equality -- and equality between arrays

text: so I think, yes, this is expected in the sense that it's not hashing every single element

Yeah, otherwise hashing arrays would always be `O(n)`, I think the way Julia samples the elements to hash for large arrays it is only `O(log n)`.
